perturbation.original_text:
8.1  XFN may terminate this Agreement by giving thirty (30) days written notice
to the CEIS.
perturbation.changed_text:
8.1  XFN may terminate this Agreement by giving five (5) days written notice
to the CEIS.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the termination notice period to five days creates a contradiction. While Hong Kong law allows parties to agree on termination clauses, such clauses must be reasonable. A five-day notice period for a 20-year agreement could be deemed unreasonable and challenged in court, as it doesn't provide CEIS sufficient time to find an alternative licensee or mitigate potential losses.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates principles of reasonableness and fairness in contract law under Hong Kong law.

perturbation.original_text:
8.2  Either Party may terminate this Agreement:
     (a)  if the other Party commits a material breach of this Agreement which
          is not capable of being remedied;
     (b)  if the other Party commits a material breach of this Agreement which
          is capable of being remedied but not remedied within thirty (30) days
          upon receiving written notice from the non-breaching party requiring
          remedy; and
     (c)  if the other Party becomes insolvent or bankrupt.
perturbation.changed_text:
8.2  Either Party may terminate this Agreement:
     (a)  if the other Party commits any breach of this Agreement, regardless of materiality or remediability;
     (b) (REMOVED FOR CONFLICT) if the other Party commits a material breach of this Agreement which
          is capable of being remedied but not remedied within thirty (30) days
          upon receiving written notice from the non-breaching party requiring
          remedy; and
     (c)  if the other Party becomes insolvent or bankrupt.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying clause 8.2(a) to allow termination for *any* breach, regardless of its materiality or whether it can be fixed, is contradictory. Under Hong Kong contract law, termination rights are generally reserved for 'material breaches' that substantially undermine the contract's purpose. Terminating for trivial, easily rectified breaches is generally not permitted and could be viewed as a breach of good faith or an abuse of contractual power. This creates a potential conflict as the original clause impliedly recognizes the 'materiality' standard, whereas the modified clause eliminates it.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with principles of 'material breach' required for contract termination under Hong Kong contract law.

perturbation.changed_text:
15.  NOTICE
     Each notice, demand or other communication given or made under this
     Agreement shall
                                      -6-
     be in writing and delivered or sent to the relevant Party's Managing
     Director or General Manager at its aforesaid address (or such other address
     as the addressee may specify by zero days' prior written notice to the
     other Party). Any notice, demand or other communication so addressed to the
     relevant Party shall be deemed to have been delivered (a) if given or made
     by letter by hand, when actually delivered to the relevant address against
     receipt; (b) if given or made by letter by post, ten business days after
     posting; and (c) if given or made by fax, when dispatched and received in
     good order.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the notice period for address changes to zero days creates a conflict. While parties can agree on notice provisions, requiring immediate effect for address changes is unreasonable. Additionally, changing the notice period for letters posted to ten business days may violate standards regarding fairness and reasonableness, as that is an excessive amount of time for letters to arrive in Hong Kong.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with implied requirements of reasonableness and fair dealing in contractual notice provisions under Hong Kong law.
